sentences: Katerina "Katy" Garbi (Greek: Κατερίνα "Καίτη" Γαρμπή, pronounced [kateˈrina ˈceti ɣarˈbi]; born 8 June 1961) is a Greek singer active in Greece and Cyprus, with some popularity in Turkey.
section: N/A

sentences: Her career has spanned over 30 years with over 1.5 million records sold in Greece and abroad.
section: N/A

sentences: Garbi's discography is marked by several multi-platinum releases, including Arhizo Polemo (1996) and Evaisthisies (1997), two of the best-selling albums of the decade.
section: N/A

sentences: Garbi represented Greece in the annual Eurovision Song Contest in 1993 with the song "Ellada, Hora Tou Fotos", taking ninth place.
section: N/A

sentences: She later struck her biggest commercial success with To Kati (2000) in terms of unit sales.
section: N/A

sentences: Over the years, Garbi has won 11 Pop Corn Music Awards, including three for Album of the Year, and one Arion Music Award.
section: N/A

sentences: On 14 March 2010, Alpha TV ranked her among the top-certified female artists in Greece's phonographic era (since 1960), at 8th place.
section: N/A
== Early life ==

sentences: Early life ==
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Katy Garbi began her singing career with her younger sister Liana, as the "Garbi Sisters", in the summer of 1977, when she was just 16 years old and Liana just 13.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: Due to their age, their father was against their work as singers, but he did not want to stand in the way of the future that he felt their talent offered them.
section: == Early life ==

sentences: They are most remembered for the backing vocals they provided at Yannis Floriniotis's performances in the early eighties.
section: == Early life ==
== Career ==

sentences: Career ==
section: == Career ==
== Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: Early solo career ===
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: Breaking away from the duo with her sister Liana, Garbi recorded her first solo song "Sain Trope".
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: Her official debut in discography came in 1987, when she appeared as one of the artists on a new compilation album called Ta Deka Dekaria alongside other new singers including Manto, Polina, Sophia Vossou and Laurentis Mahairitsas.
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: In addition to "Sain Trope", early contributions also included a duet with Kostas Haritodiplomenos titled "Glyka".
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: With the success of the first album, the second volume was released in 1989 which featured Garbi in two new songs titled "Ah, Afto Mou Aresei" and "Zo Na S'Agapo".
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===

sentences: These early songs grabbed the attention of Greek music executives, and led her to her first record contract with CBS Records Greece, paving the way for her first studio album in 1989.
section: == Career == | === Early solo career ===
== Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===
== Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: The beginning and Eurovision ===
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: Two years after her recorded music debut, Garbi released her debut personal album titled Prova (English: Rehearsal) in 1989.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: In 1990 and 1991 she released her second and third studio albums: Gyalia Karfia (English: Glass and nails) and Entalma Silepseos (English: Arrest warrant), respectively.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: Both albums fared well and allowed her to rise in the ranks of the Greek music scene.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: By 1992, Garbi released her fourth album Tou Feggariou Anapnoes (English: The Breaths of the Moon).
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: Garbi took on a more pop approach to her music, faring well with audience as she would gain her first certification when the album achieved gold certification by IFPI.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: In 1993, she accepted the offer to participate in the Eurovision Song Contest 1993 with the song "Ellada, Hora Tou Fotos", where she stirred up controversy in the Greek media due to the slitted blue dress she wore.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: Garbi's performance placed Greece 9th with 64 points.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: Garbi holds the Eurovision record for the individual singer with the longest camera close-up.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===

sentences: During her performance, the camera showed a focused close-up of Garbi, fixed for 43 seconds before cutting to a different angle.
section: == Career == | === 1989–1993: The beginning and Eurovision ===
== Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: 1994–1997: Further success ===
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: Following her highly publicized participation at Eurovision, Garbi's popularity began to climb, releasing albums that reached platinum certification, including gold album Os Ton Paradeiso (English: Until paradise) and the platinum album Atofio Hrysafi (English: Pure gold) in 1994.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: During that time, Garbi released a duet with her then boyfriend Dionisis Shinas.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: Years later he would make a marriage proposal live in front of a national TV audience while promoting the song on Mega Channel's show Bravo hosted by Roula Koromila.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: In 1996, Garbi released Arhizo Polemo (English: I'm starting a war), which was eventually certified three times platinum.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: In 1997, Garbi followed up her success by releasing her eighth studio album titled Evaisthisies (English: Sensitivities) which also reached 3× platinum status.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: The album included a duet with rising singer Antonis Remos on the song "Asimfonia Haraktiron" (English: Personality Clash).
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: That same year, Garbi also performed at Radio City Music Hall on 9 May 1997, becoming the first Greek female artist to do so.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: From 1994 to 1997, Garbi won eight Pop Corn Greek Music Awards.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

sentences: Her 1994, 1996, and 1997 releases were awarded as the best albums in each year at the Pop Corn Greek Music Awards.
section: == Career == | === 1994–1997: Further success ===

== Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: For Christmas 1998, Garbi recorded a Christmas album of popular Christmas carols titled Hristougenna Me Tin Katy (English: Christmas With Katy) all adapted with Greek lyrics by Eleni Giannatsoulia.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: The album had been a wish by Garbi for many years.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: Hristouyenna Me Tin Katy is a collaboration with well-known Greek children's choir of Spiros Labros, while the internationally known tenor Konstantinos Paliatsaras is also featured on one track.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: Since its release in 1998, sales of the album have increased with the coming of each Christmas season.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: In fact, although it was popular during the time of its release, it was not until 2002 when it gained its gold certification, four years after its release.1999 saw the release of Garbi's platinum album Doro Theou (English: Gift of God) as a dedication to her newborn baby boy Dimitris.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: The title track was written in celebration of Garbi and Shina's one year wedding anniversary.
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: Singles from the album included "Doro Theou", "Agkires", and "Aponomi Dikeosinis".
section: == Career == | === 1998–1999: Christmas album and Doro Theou ===

sentences: === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: In 2000, Garbi released her eleventh studio album titled To Kati (English: That something), a double CD with her greatest hits by Phoebus, but it also included seven new songs, four of which became singles, including a duet with fellow singer Natassa Theodoridou in the song "Epitelous", awarded Best Duet/Collaboration at the Pop Corn Music Awards of 2000.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: To Kati was certified 4× platinum, and remains one of the best selling albums of the 2000s.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: In the same year, the Greek faction of the Eurovision OGAE submitted "To Kati" to the international OGAE Song Contest.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: In representing all of Greece with the song, Katy took 5th place with 103 points, behind Sweden, Italy, Turkey and Spain.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: After the success of To Kati, Garbi partnered up with fellow Greek singer and friend Anna Vissi for a duet titled "Kalitera I Dio Mas" on Vissi's album Kravgi.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: The song was a massive radio success, with two music videos being made; Version A and Version B, fun videos that saw Garbi and Vissi lightheartedly playing around as friends.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: For the winter season of 2000-2001, Garbi appeared with Anna Vissi and boyband One at Club Fever.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: On December 15, 2000, Garbi released the maxi single "Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou" which was certified platinum.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: "Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou" featured three new songs and two remixes of the title track which was a collaboration with the popular Greek pop rock band Exis.
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: Kostas Tournas wrote one of the B-side tracks called "Kane To Logariasmo".
section: == Career == | === 2000–2001: To Kati, Anna Vissi and Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou ===

sentences: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: In 2001, Garbi released her twelfth studio album titled Apla Ta Pragmata (English: Things are simple), a double CD featuring 31 tracks and produced by Yannis Doulamis.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: The first CD features songs composed by Nikos Terzis, who also had written Garbi's earlier hit single "Pesto M' Ena Fili" as well as a duet with the young duo Antique titled "Einai Adiko Kai Krima".
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: The album included the hits "Viastika" and "Thelo Apopse Na Horepso".
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: Apla Ta Pragmata was certified 2× platinum in Greece and in Cyprus and earned Garbi the Modern Laiko Female Singer of the Year award at the Arion Music Awards.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: In 2002, Sony Music released the EP Remix Plus and the non-stop compilation CD titled Katy Garbi Hit Mix.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: In late 2002, Garbi released the EP Mia Kardia (English: One Heart), which was certified 2× platinum on the Greek Singles Chart.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: "Mia Kardia" became a hit in Greek clubs, characterized by a mix of sounds including a tsifteteli song, a techno-infused club song, a Hindi inspired song, and a duet with Giorgos Tsalikis.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: In 2003, Garbi worked with the group 667 on a song titled "Aeraki" which was included on the group's album.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: Later on that year Garbi released the album Emmones Idees (English: Obsessive idees); "Na Pernas", "Andres", "Esena Mono", and a duet with Yiannis Vardis titled "Poso Tha Thela" were well received singles from the album.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: In first for the Greek recording industry, a bonus DVD was released with the album containing the music videos and behind-the-scenes footage from Mia Kardia.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: Within a week, Emmones Idees had sold over 30,000 units achieving golden certification, heading steadily towards becoming platinum.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: To celebrate, Sony Music and whisky label Dewar's held an official presentation of the new gold album as well as a multi-platinum award ceremony of Garbi's past albums which had not officially been awarded certification plaques for reaching status sales.
section: == Career == | === 2001–2003: Apla Ta Pragmata, The Remixes and Emmones Idees ===

sentences: The albums and singles awarded were: Mia Kardia (Platinum), Apla Ta Pragmata (2x Platinum), Ti Theloune Ta Matia Sou (Platinum), To Kati (4x Platinum), Doro Theou (Gold), Hristougenna Me Tin Katy (Gold).

sentences: In 2004, Garbi released her second EP titled Galazio Kai Lefko (English: Blue and white), a title reflecting the national colors of Greece as a dedication to her country.

sentences: It also featured a new high bass song titled "Katapliktiko" and two remixes of "Esena Mono", which gained airplay and a number one position on the club charts.

sentences: The "Esena Mono" remixes also gained success in other countries such as Russia, Bulgaria, and Turkey.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: In 2005, Garbi released her moderately successful 14th studio album "Eho Sta Matia Ourano" (English: I Have A Sky In My Eyes) which achieved gold certification in Greece and Cyprus.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: The album was written by Christos Dantis and also featured a duet between the two under the title "Spaciba Baby".
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: Other songs that gained radio airplay included the pop single "Akouse Agori Mou", which Garbi performed at the 2005 Mad Video Music Awards.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: That same year Garbi was a judge on the fourth and final installment of the hit talent music show Fame Story, where she presented the song "Isovios Desmos", a duet between her and contestant Stathis Raftopoulos.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: The song made history as it was the first ever digital download track released in Greece.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: Later that year Garbi recorded the Greek song "Stohos" composed by popular Turkish singer Nazan Öncel for Planetworks, a dance and electronic label based in Greece, on their album Al Bazaar 3.
section: == Career == | === 2004–2005: Galazio Kai Lefko and Eho Sta Matia Ourano ===

sentences: Her song "Esena Mono" was mixed with the Turkish hit "Leili" by Mokka and became a music video named "Mokka vs. Katy Garbi".

sentences: On 23 October 2006, Garbi released her 15th studio album Pos Allazei O Kairos (English: How the weather changes).
section: == Career == | === 2006–2007: Pos Allazei O Kairos and live album ===

sentences: It was certified gold, with the title track "Pos Allazei O Kairos" making the highest played radio singles of the 2000s.
section: == Career == | === 2006–2007: Pos Allazei O Kairos and live album ===

sentences: On 31 August 2007, Garbi held a special charity concert at the Municipal Theatre in Aigaleo, Athens to benefit the victims and families affected by the 2007 Greek forest fires.
section: == Career == | === 2006–2007: Pos Allazei O Kairos and live album ===

sentences: The concert was recorded and released as Garbi's first live album 18 Hronia Live (English: 18 years live), composed of Laika tracks originally recorded by other artists and various hits from Garbi's discography.

sentences: 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Appearances included Chicago, Los Angeles, Toronto, Astoria, Washington DC, Vancouver, Boston, and Tampa.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: After her North America tour, Garbi returned to Greece where a party was held in celebration of her 18 years of live performancea and to present the respective live album 18 Hronia Live on 11 March 2008.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: In July 2008, Garbi released a dance-pop remix of her old song "Tzini" as a digital download.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: It was first released in 1990 on her album Gyalia Karfia and penned by Giannis Nikolaou.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: The song was remixed by Giorgos Alkaios and Dionysis Schinas of Friends Music Factory and is her second digital download only single release after "Isovios Desmos" in 2006.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: For the winter season of 2008-2009, Garbi began performances with Notis Sfakianakis at Club Enastron, after years of a rumored collaboration.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Garbi and Sfakianakis premiered on November 14, 2008 and performed weekly from Thursday to Sunday until around Easter.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: In mid-2008, it was announced that Garbi was working on songs for a new album, entirely penned by Nikos Antipas.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: The first single from Garbi's seventeenth studio album, titled Kainourgia Ego (English: A New Me), is "Afto Aksizo", a zeibekiko which was released and performed live at the premier of her performances at Club Enastron.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: The second single from the album was the title track "Kainourgia Ego" which was released to coincide with the release of the album in late December 2008.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Kainourgia Ego was set to be repackaged with three other songs and a remix with Nikos Antipas continuing the music composition and the three lyricists (GML, R. Roussi, V. Gerothodorou) also writing one of each of the new tracks, however as the production of Garbi's following album was underway, the prepackage was cancelled with its material announced to be included in the new album.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: On an episode of Mega Star on 30 November 2008, Garbi addressed rumours of her switching record labels, stating that Kainourgia Ego will be the last album she is obligated to release on her current contract with Sony BMG Greece, and that she has given thought to switching music labels.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Garbi planned to perform 15 shows at Polis Studio as part of the 2009/2010 winter music season titled "Kainourgia Ego".
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Kainourgia Ego premiered on the 13 December 2009, opening its doors every Sunday and Monday to the public in a music scene designed and directed by Vassilis Myrianthopoulos and Olga Laskaratou, with music overseen by Nikos Antipas.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: Kainourgia Ego at Polis Studio was a success, where Garbi and her guest performers were called back for an encore performance almost every night.
section: == Career == | === 2008–2009: Kainourgia Ego ===

sentences: However, Kainourgia Ego at Polis Studio closed before its due date as a result of disagreements between the venue and the shows production team.

sentences: === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: On 3 November, the lead single "Ta Iheia", originally planned for the repackage of Kainourgia Ego was released through internet music news website Starnews.gr, announcing the 2009 re-release of the album.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: A photo shoot for the artwork of the album took place on 7 November, directed by John Mitropoulos.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: In an interview with Love Radio, the station that exclusively premiered the first single "Oi Skepseis", Garbi announced that the production of the album Pazl was underway.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: The album was her second studio album composed by Nikos Antipas, continuing with the genre of previous album Kainourgia Ego which had an alternative yet laiko music style.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: Three of the album's tracks were originally planned to be incorporated into a repackage of the previous album, however, that project did not materialize.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: The year also saw Garbi announce her intentions to part ways with Sony Music Greece where she had been for the last 24 years, stating in an interview with Ihos Fm:...the situation is progressing quietly.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: I believe all I had to give, I have given, and all they had to give, they have also given.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: I'm sure that my fans are very pleased with my decision to leave Sony, due to the fact that the last few years, I have not been supported and backed by the label to the extent that is expected.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: It will be all for the best.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: Subsequently in June 2010, "OK" magazine confirmed her label departure as well as the release of a new album composed by Nikos Antipas.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: The magazine announced that Garbi and Antipas would release two new singles in the summer prior to the album's release, although this did not materialize.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: In September 2010, Garbi released a remix of her song "Kanourgia Ego".
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: On 19 February 2011, Garbi's new album, Pazl was digitally released exclusively through major Greek website "In.gr", with users able to download the entire track listing as a gift for a limited time.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: The site also featured an exclusive interview, in which Garbi noted that the album will also be released in CD format in the coming weeks.
section: == Career == | === 2010–2011: Label change and Pazl ===

sentences: Following an interview with collaborating lyricist, Manos Eleftheriou, album composer Nikos Antipas announced that the album would be released officially to stores by the end on March.

sentences: Following the termination of the free promotional giveaway of the album, Garbi later revealed on her official website that the album will be released on her new label Universal Music Greece.

== Personal life ==

sentences: Personal life ==
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Garbi and fellow Greek singer Dionisis Schinas dated for a lengthy period during the early 1990s, including 1993 when Garbi participated in a duet with him.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Rumors began to surface that the duet put them in something a lot deeper than a normal business collaboration, however in the coming months, they were to take separate paths and continue on with their solo careers.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: In the time after they both were seeing other people, Dionisis was seen various times with Greek singer Elli Kokkinou who was entering into the music industry.
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: They soon broke up and on May 4, 1997, (after a live wedding proposal)
section: == Personal life ==

sentences: Garbi married singer Dionisis Schinas and on November 11, 1999, the couple had their first child together, a boy.
section: == Personal life ==
